dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL PETERSEN (70s) wakes up to her alarm, the clock dig showing 6:00 sharp. A golden retriever DOG is at the foot her bed. He lifts his head as she responds to the alarm. Carol sits up in bed and the dog follows her movements, turning his head, both of them moving slowly. She pets th dog.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hey, Hazel. You sleep any better last night? INT. CAROL'S HOUSE - SIDE DOOR ENTRY —- MORNING 1A Carol removes Hazel’s leash from a coat hook and attaches to Hazel’s collar before going out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol, looking groggy but dressed in sharp-looking joggin clothes, walks the dog through her neighborhood. The dog hesitant and Carol needs to cajole the dog into motion wi each stop. Carol’s neighbor MIKE (late 70s/early 80s) approaches, walking his dog, and stops. The two dogs nuzzle each othe in a familiar way.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hey Mike.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: How's Hazel?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Don’t know. I don’t like the looks of him this morning. He's been having some rough nights. Walking funny.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Goddamned cancer.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: He doesn’t complain. He acts like nothing’s going on.  10

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: He sure looks chipper right now.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: He’s chatting with his buddy.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: (pausing to look at Carol) You're his buddy, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the inside of Carol’s home, which is extremely cle and tidy. We see some photographs in her living room: Car and a handsome MAN, at a table, smiling. Carol and the sa man on a boat. And a young, beaming Carol in a black and white photo, circa 1960s, singing in a folk duo. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - DINING AREA - MORNING 4 Carol sits at a table drinking coffee. She has a New York Times in her hands. Hazel is in the room with her, standi facing the wall, wagging his tail while he eats his breakfast. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - KITCHEN - MORNING 5 Carol takes some pills and vitamins with water.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE OMITTED 6
dialogues.text: EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY 7 Carol waters some of her plants. Hazel sleeps poolside.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE OMITTED 8
dialogues.text: EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY 9 Carol eats a sandwich by her pool. She gives Hazel a piec of sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RETIREMENT COMMUNITY GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: Carol hits a ball with a club while her friend SALLY (65) watches.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Nice shot, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol plays bridge as has a laugh with a GROUP OF FRIENDS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol sits on the bed and watches TV with a glass of wine Hazel lies next to her in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol wakes up before the alarm goes off, as if she’s hea something. The clock says 5:20. Hazel is not in bed with her. Carol gets out of bed and goes looking for the dog, calling for him. We stay on the empty bed.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hazel? Hazel? Carol sighs as she finds the dog.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, Hazel. You not feeling so good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol sits in a chair beside her dog in a euthanasia room Carol’s eyes are red-rimmed, exhausted. She leans over Ha and embraces him, stroking his fur. She takes his paw, wh is wrapped in medical tape and fitted with an IV catheter

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I guess this is goodbye, boy, but the hell if I know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 CLOSE UP on the dog’s face. The dog pants and his eyes ar glazed over.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I should say you’re going to a better place, shouldn't I? Nothing but doggies. (pauses) Maybe you don’t wanna hear about that. Maybe you better just wait and see. (she takes a deep breath) I’m just gonna sit with you as long as they let me. Carol sits in silence and looks fondly at the dog. A VET opens the door and Carol looks up. Carol knows it’s time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP on Carol’s face as the Vet administers the injections, which we hear but do not see. While the Vet speaks, Carol pets Hazel.

dialogues.speaker: VET
dialogues.text: (softly) I'm giving him the sedative now. He may close his eyes. (pauses) Okay. Now he’s very relaxed. (pauses) I’m going to inject the pentobarbital. This will stop his heart. After a long pause the Vet puts on a stethoscope and list for a heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: VET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: His heart has stopped. (pauses) I’m very sorry. Take as much time as you need. The VET leaves the room. Carol sits with Hazel. INT. CAROL’S CAR (EXT. ANIMAL HOSPITAL) - DAY 18 Carol, wearing sunglasses to hide tears, heads to hear ca and gets in. She starts her car. “I Never Dreamed” by The Cookies is on the radio. Carol lets it play and drives of  19 20 21 22 23 24 25

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol drives down a quaint neighborhood street. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - STREET - DAY 20 Carol pulls next to her house. INT. CAROL’S CAR (EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - STREET) - DAY 21 Carol sits in her car. “I Never Dreamed” continues to pla Carol just sits there, listening to the song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol walks in her house. She has Hazel’s leash in her ha She looks at it and hangs it up by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol pours herself a glass of white wine. She pauses, th adds a bit more. She has a sip and takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol is sitting in her living room. She has another sip her wine. She looks around. The house feels big and empty All the lights are off. Carol hears a rustling nearby. She looks over, then stand and takes a few tentative steps toward the sound. At firs she sees nothing, and then sees the snout of a small anim poking out from behind a cabinet. It stops moving at the sound of Carol’s footsteps. Carol stares in shock, unable speak. The animal then comes out from the cabinet and scuttles along the wall. It is a RAT. Carol screams at the top of her lungs and runs out of the living room. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY 25 Carol runs to the back doors and opens them, finally gett outside. Carol, shaken by the whole incident, looks in th door to see if she can see the rat.  26 EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY - LATER 26 Carol, having nodded off on her outdoor couch, wakes up. looks over to see LLOYD (early 30s), a pool guy, standing there with all of his pool cleaning gear. He has a pair o headphones on. He pulls the headphones down around his ne when he sees Carol staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Afternoon. (pauses) You okay?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Okay?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You seemed...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What? Are you saying you thought I was dead?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No, not that. Sorry. Lloyd begins unloading his gear by the pool, trying to av the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Because I’m an old person and I had my eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I was just making sure you were okay.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No, I’m not okay. I’m terrible. Lloyd just stares at her, unsure of what to say next.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who are you? It was always another guy. Richie? Lloyd has already moved to the edge of the pool and begun setting up his cleaning gear.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Richie, uh, moved on. He had a difference of opinion with the owners. I’m the new guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, clean away, new guy. She begins to open the door to go back inside, then hesit and shuts it. Lloyd puts his headphones on and begins assembling his gear to clean the pool, then pauses and removes the headphones.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You don’t look that old, by the way. I mean, I wasn’t worried because you look old.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (distracted) You always gotta assume the worst. Don’t worry about it. Lloyd puts his headphones back on. Carol peers into the house and then looks back at Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Um... excuse me? Lloyd removes his headphones.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I... Can I ask you a favor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol waits on pins and needles while Lloyd searches for rat.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Do you see anything?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I... do not.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Keep looking. Check behind the curtains.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Sorry, I didn’t see it. Maybe it’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh god. He’s probably going to reappear the second you leave.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Maybe you should call, like, an exterminator? Carol gives him a look and cautiously enters the house.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I can’t imagine where it came from. I haven’t even seen a mouse in years. I think my dog must've kept them away. But a rat... it was black. Like a bad omen.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: So where’s the dog?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (blankly) I had to put him down today.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Oh. Jeez, I’m sorry. Carol doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I should probably, uh, get back to work.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m sorry. Thank you... (waiting for his name)

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Lloyd. I’m Carol. Lloyd nods and half smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Uh... I’1l be right outside if the rat comes back. Carol nods and Lloyd heads out.  28 29 30 31 32

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol is reading at her dining room table with a new glas wine. Lloyd knocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (through the window) All set! Carol smiles and waves. As Lloyd walks away she just sits there, alone in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol wakes up to her alarm, the clock digits showing 6:0 sharp. INT. CAROL'S HOUSE - SIDE ENTRY —- MORNING 31 Carol heads for the door, dressed in her usual walking outfit. Carol walks out the door, leaving Hazel’s leash i it’s spot on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol walks along the sidewalk. Mike approaches with his

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You’re gonna tell me some bad news, aren’t you. When I didn’t see you guys yesterday... Carol, petting his dog, nods.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Carol. It’s hard. You should be thankful that you were able to do that for him. Carol says nothing. She isn’t choking up but she doesn’t to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Carol, if you ever need anything...  33 34 35 36 37 10.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thanks Mike. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - DINING AREA - DAY 33 Carol sits at her table drinking coffee with a copy of Th New York Times nearby. She has the Yellow Pages open to a “Exterminators” page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol takes some pills and vitamins with water. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY 35 Carol waters some of her plants by her pool. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY 36 Carol eats a salad by her pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol and the EXTERMINATOR walk through the kitchen towar the living room.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERMINATOR
dialogues.text: I suspect this was a black rat or what we call a roof rat. Very common in Southern California.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Where do you think it came from?

dialogues.speaker: EXTERMINATOR
dialogues.text: They're everywhere. They live in the trees... they’re all over the city.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERMINATOR
dialogues.text: You'd never seen signs of them before? Rodent droppings, gnaw marks on bags of pet food, anything like that? They love dog food.  38 39 40 4l 42 43 11.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERMINATOR
dialogues.text: And you haven’t seen it since yesterday? Carol shakes her head. EXTERMINATOR (CONT’D) Well, I have my doubts that the rodent is inhabiting your house. I checked the whole perimeter for points of entry and I’m not seeing any holes and there are no signs of colonization. I’ll set a few traps to make sure but I think what we have here is an isolated incident. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL AREA - DAY 38 Carol opens a garbage can lid and throws away a half-empt bag of dog food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol watches some TV with a glass of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol wakes up to her alarm, 6:00. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - DINING AREA - DAY 43 Carol sits at a table reading The New York Times. The pho rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol walks into her kitchen and picks up the cordless an looks at the caller ID with a puzzled expression, then presses the button and puts the phone to her ear.  12.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi Mom. It’s Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I saw your name on the thing... is everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just checking in... I heard about Hazel, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: How on earth did you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Rona sent me an e-mail.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Since when do you and Rona e-mail?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We e-mail, mom. We’re friends on Facebook. I’ve known her my whole life.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You never e-mail me.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You don’t ever use the computer.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: And you e-mail Rona of all people? How did she find out?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: She didn't say. Mom, I’m just... so sorry. It’s just terrible news. What happened?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: When I got up yesterday he was just... he couldn’t walk. I carried him to the car myself. They said the cancer had spread everywhere. His spine. You could tell... looking at his eyes... it was time.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You didn’t ask for help?  13.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Why. What for?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Should you even be carrying things like that...? Heavy things...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: He was a dog, Kath. Not a thing. And it was five in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I just thought you had a weight limit, after the back injury, when was that... didn’t you have surgery?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No, I didn’t have surgery.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You didn’t? I thought - your back -

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I see a chiropractor. I also play golf, I swim, I carry my own groceries. I clean this house. I... Not that you’d know, anyway. When were you last here? Right after 9/11 I think it was?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I've been there since then.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No, no... I think that was the last time. You couldn’t stand the smell or something and so you came out here.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom. I came down there to be with you. It was like going through what happened with Dad all over again -

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You spent two weeks watching CNN and talking to your boyfriend on your cell phone and never the left the house.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Everybody was that way when that happened.  44 45 46 14.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Well, that was the last time you were here. Every other time I’ve come out there. Did you ever even meet Hazel? Silence on the line.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (conciliatory) Okay, never mind - I don’t... I don’t mean to be... how did you put it? “Guilt tripping” you?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay. I’ve gotta go, Mom. I’m sorry about Hazel. I hope you’re doing okay.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: The house feels empty without him but I’m okay. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay. Love you. The phone line clicks as Katherine hangs up on the other Carol looks at the phone and clicks it off and sets it on counter. A beat later the phone rings again and she picks up on the first ring.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (irritated) What.... Yes it is.... (long pause, then quietly) Thank you. Yes. I’1l be by later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol exits the hospital carrying a paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol browses the shelves, picking up bottles and lifting pair of reading glasses to her eyes to read the labels. T scene has a tone of eavesdropping on Carol.

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: May I help you find something?  15.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m not sure. Store clerk looks at Carol patiently.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just want to be sure I’m getting enough of everything.

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: Are you taking supplements now?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I take a multivitamin... I take vitamin C. Calcium. I take some things a friend gave me... kelp?

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: (patiently) Do you have any health issues you want to address? Carol shakes her head vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No, no, it’s not...

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: Okay, so let’s look at a few more basics. Do you take any magnesium?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m not sure.

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK
dialogues.text: Magnesium is a very good anti- inflammatory, very good for the smooth muscles and the joints. It’s a good all-around anti-aging supplement. Store Clerk removes a bottle from the shelf and shows it Carol.

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This one is very popular. Carol takes the bottle and looks at the clerk over her reading glasses. While they are talking, a MAN (70s) is standing down the aisle from them with an unlit cigar in mouth, listening but not looking at them.  47 48 49 50 51 52 16.

dialogues.speaker: STORE CLERK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What about... are you doing a probiotic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol continues to look around, her basket now full of various bottles. She picks up a bottle and inspects it. T Man with the unlit cigar comes up to her as she browses.

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR MAN
dialogues.text: (pointing at bottle) You don’t need all that. Carol looks up to the Man. CIGAR MAN (CONT’D) You're just right the way you are. The Cigar Man walks away and Carol just watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol comes home with shopping bags in hand. She places t on the counter. She reaches into a paper bag and pulls ou cardboard box. She inspects it. CLOSE UP on the top of th box is a sticker that says “HAZEL: CHERISHED PET OF CAROL PETERSEN.” She opens the box and pulls out a keepsake tin INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - DAY 50 Carol heads into the living room. She puts Hazel’s ashes the keepsake tin next to a very nice vase above her fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol's car pulls into a retirement community. The sign r “ROYAL OAKS.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol walks through the retirement community. Older peopl walk around, mostly in groups and pairs. A few people sit lawn chairs outside of their apartments, chatting.  53 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol sits at a card table playing bridge with three frie RONA, GEORGINA, and SALLY, all in their early to mid-70s. hand has been dealt and the four women are holding their cards and rearranging them in their hands. Three of them are drinking white wine, with the exception Sally who is drinking a can of Budweiser.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Rona, did you see Jerry today? At the pool?

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Jerry who?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: There’s only the one Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: There’s three Jerrys!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: (counting on her fingers) Jerry Davis, Gerry Phillips, and Jerry Li.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: See?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Gerry Phillips is Gerry with a G, though. Does he count?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Do you know who he was with?

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Which one?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Jerry Davis, for Christ’s sake.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Are we playing cards, girls? Your bid, Georgina.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: One spade.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Pass.  18.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: One no trump.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Pass.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Two no trump.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Pass.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (thinking about it) Three no trump.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I'm feeling good tonight, girls. You guys are not winning tonight, I can tell you that. Sally laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Pass.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Pass. The girls start arranging their cards.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: So who the who hell was he with?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Jerry Davis.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Oh right. Jerry was with Karen. And I could've sworn she was doing you- know-what to him in the pool.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Sally!

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Not sex, Georgie. I think she was just giving him a little tug. Carol and Rona laugh. Georgina is shocked.  19.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: The language, Sally!

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: What language?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: (shivering) “Tug.”

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: How is that language? I said “tug.” I didn’t say she was “jerking him off.” Jeez...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: I don’t like that kinda talk.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: You're so sensitive, Georgie.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: I'd just rather not hear about Jerry Davis’ habits in the pool.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: That pool. It’s disgusting. Too many people are in that pool.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I love that pool.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: God knows what’s in that pool.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It doesn't seem particularly clean.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Like your pool’s a day spa.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I have it cleaned once a week.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Carol, when are you gonna move in here? A lady just passed on two cottages over. God rest her soul.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: That reminds me - they have new brochures. I want you to see the new brochures, Carol.  20.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t want to see the new brochures. I already saw the old brochures.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I‘1l bring some by this week.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Yeah, Carol. You’re missing out on all the action.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m very happy with my house, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: But that pool, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What about my pool?

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: You're all alone there! You could slip and fall and no one would be around to help you. You could drown in that pool.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Well, at least it’d be clean. The girls laugh. Some card playing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Carol, how's Hazel been feeling lately? Carol looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hazel... He, uh... (looks at Rona, then looks down at her cards) I had to put Hazel down. All at once GEORGINA and SALLY put their cards down and u hushed apologies, “Oh, Carol,” “For Christ’s sake, why di you tell us,” etc.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: A couple days ago.  21.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: That’s terrible, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (to Rona) Don’t act so surprised.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Don’t play dumb, Rona. Kath told me you told her. How'd you find out anyway?

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Mike told me.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: The guy with the dog? Your neighbor?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (to Rona) Well, aren’t you just cozy with everyone? Rona is hurt by this. Sally sees it and jumps in.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: She's just upset, Rona.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Of course she is. We all loved Hazel, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: (to Carol) How are you holding up?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I’m sorry, Ro.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: To hell with the card game. We should get good and drunk tonight. (standing) I’m getting another. And I got some of that medical marijuana...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: (to Carol) What are you going to do?  22.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: I don’t know... are you getting another dog?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: She's in mourning, Georgina. You can’t just get a new dog right after. It’s not like her car died.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I couldn't get another dog after my last one passed. It’s just too hard to replace them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: I just know you loved that boy so much. Carol doesn’t respond. The ladies look at each other. GEORGINA (CONT’D) We should do something. We should have a memorial or something. I can talk to my pastor.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Or maybe we can treat you to a nice dinner out someplace.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Look... there’s nothing left to do. He had a good life. Even the cancer didn’t bother him. So I don’t let it bother me either. I’m fine. Really. I’m gonna play some golf, do our bridge game on Wednesdays, try to live a bit longer, and God willing I don’t get the big A... (shrugs ) ...and maybe someday I’1l get another dog.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Just a dog?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Don’t start with that.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: What?  23.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: The dating talk. The second husband talk. You couldn’t pay me.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: But they do pay you. When they die.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Not always.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: And who's saying husband?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Maybe you could date somebody.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Maybe I could stick a fork in my eye.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: (to Georgina) Like you've dated since Gary passed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Once you’ve had the best, who cares about the rest.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Yeah, Rona. Not once you’ve had the best you go out and get another one and then another one and another one...

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I’ve only been married three times!

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Yeah, only three.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m with Georgina. I’m not interested and that’s that.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Jeez, Carol, come on. Don’t you ever think about it? Just somebody to go out with once in a while... What about Mike?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What about him?  24.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: He’s cute. Seems like a nice guy.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Isn’t Mike a little...old?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m not... I’m not interested in anyone right now...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: You're in that big house. All alone. We worry about you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Guys ask about you all the time, Carol. You’re a beautiful woman! I can hook you up. I know everyone here.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Like it’s that simple. If it were that simple...

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: What? You mean you gotta put out?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: (shivering again) Like with Jerry in the pool.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: That’s not what she means.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I just mean I don’t like my life all complicated. Hazel’s gone, but I like my life the way it is. It’s easy. I know where everything is. Carol looks at everyone. Everyone is looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Never mind. Are we playing cards, girls? Let’s play some cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alarm goes off. Carol wakes up and gets out of bed.  55 56 25.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RETIREMENT COMMUNITY GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: a ball on a tee. A club hits the ball. Carol watches her shot as it drives down the fairway. She clearly knows what she’s doing with a golf club. Sally is watching as well.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: What a shot, Carol! Wow.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RETIREMENT COMMUNITY GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: Sally puts and misses. Carol stands on the green nearby.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: (after missing shot) Let’s just have the maximum shot count be ten, for Christ’s sake.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: The shot count is however many strokes it took you to get the ball in the hole.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: (walking to her ball) Golf talk is so sexual-sounding isn’t it? Balls, holes, strokes...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Just count up your shots, Sally. And be honest.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: What is this, the PGA?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah, the senior-senior tour. Sally laughs and puts again. She sinks the put.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: That means I scored a thirteen on this one...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh fine. Max score can be ten.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: That’s my girl.  57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bunch of elderly people are sitting around having and enjoying themselves. Sally is at a table with Carol after their game.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You want a drink?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It’s early. And I'm driving.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I didn’t hear a no. A WAITRESS approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A Bud and a glass of chardonnay for this one. Thanks, dear. 26. 57 drinks As Sally orders, Carol looks out the window to see the CI MAN from the vitamin store talking to a few gentlemen at table on the patio. He still has an unlit cigar in his mo and seems to be in charge of the conversation. After the Waitress leaves Sally turns around and spots wh Carol is looking at.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s handsome.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: That guy.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Which one? The Cigar Man laughs and has a sip of his whiskey. looks at Carol as if to say, “You know which one.”

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've seen him before. He talked to me at the store the other day.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Really? He talked to you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah... Sally

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Something about I’m just fine the way I am...

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t remember.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Oh my god. He’s sexy, Carol. He must be new. I can find out. Sally stands to head over and Carol stops her, making her back down.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Don’t go over there.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Look at you, like a nervous schoolgirl. What are you afraid of? Carol just makes a disapproving face.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why don’t you come with me tomorrow night to this speed dating thing -

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m not doing that.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: C’mon, Carol. They do it right inside the clubhouse. It’1l be good for you. It’s fun.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’ll bet.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You meet some fellas, you talk a little. It’s not even dating. It’s just socializing. It’s no big deal. (pointing to the Cigar Man) Maybe he’1l be there.  58 59 60 61 28. Carol looks up to see the Cigar Man looking at her. They eyes for a moment and then the Waitress comes with drinks Carol looks away. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY 58 Carol has a glass of wine by her pool. It’s clear that sh had a few since her date with Sally. She notices somethin her pool and heads over. She looks in the pool and sees t the automatic cleaning device is not moving. She makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Okay.... Thank you. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - DAY 60 The cleaning device is back in the pool, roving around.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Like new.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thank you. What was the problem?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Um... They tend not to work so well when they come unplugged. Carol shakes her head, knowing how silly the problem was.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Ah...

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You mind if I use your bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd comes out of the bathroom and sees Carol's pictures focuses on the one of her in a folk band. He looks more closely to see a YOUNG CAROL with a HANDSOME MAN in a bla and white photo from the sixties. They have instruments i their hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long time ago. 29. Lloyd looks up to see Carol staring at the photo with him

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You were a musician? Carol nods her head.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I was in a folk duo. That was in New York, a million years ago. We used to play in the Village. I sang.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: That your husband? CLOSE ON: The photo and the handsome man with his arm aro Young Carol. Their pose and look of contentment suggest t they are together.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No. That’s John.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: My husband came later. Bill. Carol indicates another photo, the one we saw earlier of Carol and an older man, their arms around each other, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I used to be in a band...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I sang, too. If you can call it that.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Where were you in a band?  30.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Austin. I just moved back here, SO...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What brought you back?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I grew up in the Valley. Austin didn’t work out.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (knowingly) I’m sure you're better off without her.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Right now it feels like it’s the other way around. (smiling) You're pretty smart for an old lady.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You have family here?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m staying with my mom. Carol looks at him as if reassessing him while trying not appear to be doing so. He’s a little old to be living bac home. LLOYD (CONT’D) Temporarily.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Friends?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Not really. Not anymore, no.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You want a drink? I was about to open a bottle of wine. Well, another bottle.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m still on the clock.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh come on. My dog just died. Pretend to have a drink with me.  62 31. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - DINING AREA - DAY 62 Carol pops open a bottle and begins pouring Lloyd a glass

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You want just a little or you want the full treatment?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Fill ‘er up. She does the same for herself and lifts her glass.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Cheers, Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Cheers. They touch glasses and have a sip. Lloyd shakes his head, enjoying the wine.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is really good.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I think so, too. So what kind of music do you sing?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: The closest I get to singing anymore is karaoke night at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: But lately I’ve been writing some songs.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: So you’re a songwriter?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: No... but I studied poetry in college. This is sort of the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You mean you went to school to write poetry?  32.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah. B.F.A.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Bet your parents loved you for that.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hence the pool guy getup.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No one’s hiring poets, huh?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Not currently. Not for like the past ten years. Lloyd smiles. There’s an awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But someday I’1l have a lot of good poems about... pools. Carol laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I bet you will.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: But it seems like - I mean, you were in a real group.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: For a bit, yeah. That gentleman in the picture played guitar.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: The one who’s not your husband.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Right. John.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: John was pretty handsome.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: He certainly had a way about him...

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You divorced, or?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: My husband? He died.  63 33. They each have another sip of wine. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - EVENING 63 Time has passed and another bottle has been opened. Carol Lloyd are both a bit tipsy. They share a big laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Well, I guess they set it up so you meet a new person every few minutes or something. It sounds awful.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Well, it’s an experience, right?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: It might be fun. Why not? Carol thinks it over and has another sip of wine.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (to herself, tipsy) Yeah, why not... Lloyd smiles at Carol.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (checking his phone) I gotta run. Got to meet my mom for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh sure. Sorry I kept you.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? I had a great time. You’re a good drinking buddy.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You're sweet to say that.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (going to gather his gear) I’m not just saying it. Carol smiles while Lloyd goes to gather his gear. As he’s getting it together he looks back at Carol.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, what happened to that rat?  64 34.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It... left. I think. The guy says it was an “isolated incident.” Whatever that means. Lloyd nods. There is some silence between them.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You know, do you wanna... hang out some time? Carol looks at Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not like that. I mean... Lloyd gestures helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Like this. But not here. I mean we should go out. Carol raises her eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not... not... go out. I just mean, if you're interested, maybe we could go do karaoke or something? I’d love to see you get up there and knock ‘em dead. Carol laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Okay. Cool. Lloyd heads out. Carol sits for a beat and then finishes wine by the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A paper flyer that says “Speed Dating - This Wa with an arrow. Carol and Sally enter the common room. Several women are sitting on one side of a long table wit pitchers of iced tea and drink glasses filled. A few othe women are standing up and talking. The other side of the table is empty.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: There are no men here.  35.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: They’1l be here. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I can’t believe I agreed to this.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Hey, you called me.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I was drunk. My decision-making skills were at an extreme low. The woman who runs the speed dating is LESLIE HANSEN (60s Leslie taps a spoon on a glass.

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE
dialogues.text: Welcome everyone. Welcome. Let’s settle in. The few women still standing find their seats. Carol and Sally end up seated remotely from each other. As Leslie talks we see the women watching her and listening, but Ca is watching the other women, looking around nervously. Ca seems to already regret her decision.

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I see some familiar faces, some new faces... this is going to be really fun. (points) The “boys” are waiting in the next room, and in a just a minute we'll open the door and they’re going to come in... and we'll begin. Carol leans back and looks to Sally, who is down the tabl Sally leans back to look at her.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (to Sally) They’re gonna unleash them on us like the bulls in Pamplona?

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE
dialogues.text: Each “date” is five minutes long, and then we shift down the table to the next date. When I tap the spoon (taps spoon on glass) - that’s your thirty-second warning that it’s time for the men to shift to the next chair. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s when you want to start thinking about exchanging information, if that’s something you want to do. Okay? Are we ready? No one answers. The women just look around.

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh come on! We can’t do better than that? Are you ready? A few audible “Yeah’s” and “Yes’s” are heard. A woman pic up her iced tea and sips it.

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s more like it! The door is opened and a dozen older men come streaming o into the room and sit down at the table across from the ladies. The Cigar Man is not among them. Carol gives Sall look that says “shoot me now.”

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (taps spoon on glass) Let the dating begin! The table instantly becomes a sea of chatter as the men b talking to the ladies. OLD GUY 1, a bald man with a rim of white hair and a swee face, is seated across from Carol. His name tag says “Car

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 1
dialogues.text: Hello. Carol, huh? That’s funny. Carol looks puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 1, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Carol, Carl. Carol notices his name tag.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 1
dialogues.text: Your first time here?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes.  37.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 1
dialogues.text: Same. I’ve had some girlfriends, but I’m looking for someone, you know, special. To go to the movies, have a nice dinner out? That’s a dime a dozen. But someone who's there for you all the time, to go on walks every day, you know, a companion. Carol nods. Awkward silence. OLD GUY 1 (CONT’D) So what kind of interests do you have?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (leaning forward) Interests?

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 1
dialogues.text: Yeah. Like...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Like what do I like to do?

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 1
dialogues.text: Yeah. Carol has to think about this for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You mean by myself, or with other people?

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 1
dialogues.text: Either one. Carol looks bewildered. She pours herself some iced tea.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: How about you tell me about your interests. Old Guy 1 looks confused. Carol grabs her glass of iced t

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 1
dialogues.text: I guess my interest right now is you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I think I’m...  65 38. Leslie taps her spoon on glass. Carol flinches, looking towards her.

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE
dialogues.text: Thirty seconds! Prepare to shift!

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. Old Guy 1 looks expectantly at Carol and Carol ignores hi until the woman taps the spoon on her glass again. Old Gu smiles and nods goodbye and stands, as do the rest of the men, and shifts to the next chair. OLD GUY 2 sits down.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 2
dialogues.text: I’m gonna cut to the chase here. Is that okay? Carol looks at him, suddenly interested. This guy is intriguing. OLD GUY 2 (CONT’D) Sex is still very important to me.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 2
dialogues.text: And if we were to go out I'd like to get right to it, if you know what I mean. We don’t have much time left - no offense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The following montage is quick cuts of older men talking Carol as they speed date.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 3
dialogues.text: I just moved here from Florida. It’s so cold here. The nights! So frigid. No one told me you have to carry a sweater around with you at all times in California. Nothing like the postcard!

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 4
dialogues.text: The most important thing is that you're around all of the time. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 4, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not looking to spend the rest of my life away from a beautiful woman like you. I want to be around you. All of the time.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 3
dialogues.text: And it’s too cold indoors. This AC is out of control, like what, they're trying to refrigerate us? I’m telling you, you have to carry a sweater with you wherever you go.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 5
dialogues.text: Barry Manilow is coming to town and who doesn’t love Barry Manilow.

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 2
dialogues.text: The other stuff is important too, but sex is the most important. At our age - what do we have to lose? What am I afraid of, herpes? So I have herpes for a few years and then what, I’m dead anyway. I mean, I don’t have herpes, but I don’t care if you do. Let’s have some fun, huh?

dialogues.speaker: OLD GUY 4
dialogues.text: If I’m with you, I want you around me. The last woman I dated - she was never around. She was always going to some bridge club or a movie, coffee with friends. I can’t have that. Is that so much to ask? Leslie taps her spoon on a glass. END MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol and Sally walk away from the Community Building. Ca is visibly dismayed while Sally is trying to appear upbea

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: That wasn’t so bad, right? Carol stops walking.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Not so bad? I live a long healthy life for this? What the hell was I doing in there?  67 40. Some other speed daters are leaving the building and cast looks at them.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Oh, lighten up.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Did you talk to the herpes guy?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: One of them had herpes?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No, he - he didn’t care if I did. Sally gives a Carol a look.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is upsetting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 Carol puts the groceries in the trunk of her car. A car pulls up behind her, a nice luxury car. The Cigar Man is driving and he honks the horn. This makes Carol jump and around, perturbed. She recognizes Cigar Man and points at him.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You!

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR MAN
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR MAN
dialogues.text: I want to have lunch with you. What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR MAN
dialogues.text: Your name is Yes?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes, I'll have lunch with you.

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR MAN
dialogues.text: Just like that?  41.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: How else would you like it to be? The Cigar Man looks at her as if thinking the question ov seriously. A car behind him honks its horn.

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR MAN
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) Now.

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR MAN
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m hungry.

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR MAN
dialogues.text: Won’t your groceries spoil? Just give me your number. I’11 call you and ask you out properly.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You're on your way to a date right now. Is that it? The HORN honks again.

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR MAN
dialogues.text: Just give me your number.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You don’t have a pen and paper.

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR MAN
dialogues.text: Well, we seem to be in a real bind here... I’1l remember your number.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Your brain still that sharp, huh?

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR MAN
dialogues.text: Try me. Carol looks around and then back at the Cigar Man. The ca behind Cigar Man HONKS again.

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR MAN
dialogues.text: Got it. Is that your cell phone?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t have a cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR MAN
dialogues.text: No? Okay, I’1ll call you... But who am I calling?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Carol.

dialogues.speaker: CIGAR MAN
dialogues.text: Carol. It’s Bill. Bill drives off. She stands in the parking lot watching h drive away.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (to herself) Bill... Christ. 68 INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - DAY 68 Carol sits slouched on her couch watching TV with a glass wine. She gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol goes to the kitchen with her wine and picks up the phone, looks for a number in her address book. She dials number.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hello, I - I’m looking for Lloyd? (waits) Ah. Is he - (she listens) Could I just leave a message? 70 INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - DAY 70 Carol is slouched on the couch reading a book. The phone rings and Carol picks up the cordless.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey Carol - it’s Lloyd. Got your message. Everything okay with the pool sweep?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Lloyd. Listen, Lloyd. Any karaoke going on tonight?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Um - I’m sure there is. Somewhere. I could find a place.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That sounds nice... Silence on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sorry, I’m thinking. I’m just making sure I don’t have anything - is this like a date?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It’s whatever. Does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I guess not.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: So you'll pick me up?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah yeah -

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd and Carol walk into the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd and Carol enter the bar, which is on the empty side looks just like a regular dive bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are mostly men in the bar, drinking alone. The Kara hasn't started yet but a GUY is finishing setting up the equipment. Lloyd and Carol sit at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Have you been here before? Lloyd shakes his head with a nervous smile.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: What can I get you? Lloyd gestures at Carol as if to let her order first.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I'll have whatever you’re having.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Two Modelos. Carol looks over to the guy getting the mic set up. The b arrive and Carol lifts the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Cheers. Lloyd clinks bottles with her. Lloyd does not appear to b at ease and Carol seems to pick up on this.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is good. I needed this.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Rough day at the office?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Not exactly that. There is an awkward silence between them.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Guess we got here a little early.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Shouldn’t this be happy hour?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Eh... Nowadays people don’t go out until late.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What time?  74 45.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Even on a weeknights?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Don’t people have jobs?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Not so much anymore... Lloyd and Carol have a swig of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GUY sings a karaoke song. Lloyd and Carol are still at bar leafing through the notebook of karaoke songs. The Bartender comes over with an APPLE MARTINI for Carol.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: There you go.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thank you. Carol has a sip.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, this is good. (to Lloyd) This is good.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (to bartender) What did you make me?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: It’s uh... an apple-tini.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Apple-tini. I’m gonna write that down. Carol writes down “Apple-tini” on a coaster and puts it i her purse. Carol goes back to the karaoke notebook. She n her head as if she’s found something.  75 46.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think I got one.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah? Which one?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Not telling.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah. I think I can do this one. Now you.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I know which one.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Already?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I always do the same tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd is in the middle of his song. He’s singing “I Think We’re Alone Now” by Tiffany. He sings passably well, performing the song goofily as if he has done it many tim before. Carol watches with a smile. Scattered applause when he’s finished. The place is filli up. He goes back to Carol at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That was good.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (looking around) Looks like that ten o’clock crowd is starting to filter in.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah. You ready? Did you put your name down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol approaches the stage, picks up the microphone. She looks tentative at first but lifts the microphone and beg to sing. The song is “Cry Me A River” by Diana Krall. Her voice wavers over the first few lines of the song, bu the first chorus she is killing it, and much of the chatt in the bar has quieted - people are locking into it. By t last chorus, random people are whooping and clapping befo she’s even finished. When she’s finished, whistles and cheers and generous clapping. She returns to the bar. Lloyd is looking at her with new appreciation.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Jesus, that gave me goosebumps. That was great. Bartender sets another APPLE MARTINI on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: On the house. Carol picks up the drink and has a big sip. Her hand is trembling.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Look at me. I’m shaking.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: You can sing, lady. (to Lloyd) This your mom?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I wish.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Can we go?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Already?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I gotta quit while I’m ahead here, I think.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You are definitely ahead.  77 78 48. INT. LLOYD'S CAR (EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE) - NIGHT 77 Carol and Lloyd are parked in front of Carol’s place. “Le Be Still” by The Head and The Heart is playing quietly on Lloyd’s car stereo.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thank you for a lovely evening. Carol sits for a moment, then starts to get out of the ca

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: So how come you quit singing?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t remember why. I woke up one day and I wasn’t singing anymore. Thanks again, Lloyd. Lloyd nods.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want some coffee? Lloyd makes a face, hesitant.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, really, I’m making coffee. Don’t be an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd and Carol drink coffee out of big, colorful, breakf looking mugs, Carol sitting on the couch and Lloyd in an chair.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t even listen to music anymore. Just in the car, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I still have all my old records right in there. Carol nods in the direction of a media cabinet.  49.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t remember the last time I put one on.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Let’s fucking put one on right now.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Be my guest. Lloyd sets down his coffee and goes to the media cabinet opens the doors. The cabinet is filled with LP records. I the middle is an old hi-fi with a turntable. Carol watche him move his index finger along the spines of the records He pulls out a record and turns on the hi-fi.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: This is a beautiful turntable.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It was Bill’s. He was very picky about stereo equipment. Lloyd drops the needle on a Billie Holiday record. “They Can't Take That Away From Me” begins playing. Lloyd liste to the song for a bit. Carol watches him thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What kind of plans do you have, Lloyd?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m not in a plan-making place.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: More like I’m just trying to sock some money away for now.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You gotta be careful with that. It might be all you end up doing.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Fine by me. I’ve been trying to figure out how to do it all my life. Hasn’t exactly worked out so far. Is that what you did?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Something like that.  50.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (heading back to where Carol is) So how’d you earn your money?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I was a teacher. What they used to call a schoolteacher.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: What’d you teach?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I taught all the classes nobody else wanted to teach. Like Health. And Typing.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: And you saved up money and retired on that?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No. On Bill’s life insurance. I retired early when he died.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: So he died young.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It was an accident... a plane crash. It was a big news story for a long time after. A lot of people died. He was on a business trip.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: When was that?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Twenty years ago this spring. You can Google it. Was one of the big ones. Lloyd is quiet for a moment, listening closely to the son

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: See, now hearing that makes me want to live in the moment. Screw the job.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Can’t have it both ways, huh?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I guess.  51. Carol sips her coffee.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You don't get it because you're young. You're looking forward to everything.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I sure don’t feel like I’m looking forward to anything.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: A break-up can do that to you.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Well... that happened, but I guess really I came back because of my mother. She’s got some health issues... nothing serious, but I’m here taking care of her. I’m not even sure she likes having me around. My dad died a few years ago and I’m just... trying to be responsible. Trying to do the right thing. My other siblings are... busy, I guess. With kids and real jobs and hectic schedules and travel plans. Carol looks at Lloyd for a beat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You are doing the right thing, Lloyd. That’s a noble thing you're doing. Lloyd shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just know that no matter what you do, everything's gonna run together by the time you're 50.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just - time goes by quicker. I don’t know, maybe if my daughter had gotten married, if I had some grandchildren... maybe that would've slowed things down here and there.  52. Carol sips her coffee again and makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People talk about living in the moment, like it’s some kind of goal. But what does that even mean?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I think it just means don’t let yourself be weighed down by what you think you should be doing, right?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That's just... impossible. There’s no such thing as that.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Sure there is. You didn’t feel it when you were singing?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Feel what?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Like you were only doing that thing. You stop being aware of everything else. Like everything wrong with your life just disappears.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: But people can spend their whole lives doing that, waiting for that feeling, trying to find that feeling over and over again...

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: And in the end, everybody gets it. We wait our whole lives for something and we get it. And you know what it is?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Happiness?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It’s death.  79 80 81 53. Lloyd sips his coffee and nods, looking very serious. Car nods back at him, also looking serious, then bursts out laughing. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - BEDROOM - MORNING 79 Carol wakes up to her alarm, the clock digits showing 6:0 sharp. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - MORNING 80 Carol walks into the living room, where Lloyd is asleep o the couch.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Rise and shine. Lloyd opens his eyes. He looks befuddled.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You fell asleep and I didn’t know what to do. So I just left you there.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: That Billie probably lulled me down. Carol doesn’t say anything. Lloyd rubs his eyes and sits

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’1l make you some coffee but then you should go. I... I have to get on with my day here. Lloyd looks at her, then looks away.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Okay... Carol awkwardly smiles at him and goes into the kitchen. Lloyd looks around and starts to gather his things to hea out. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - STREET - MORNING 81 Rona pulls in front of Carol’s house, behind Lloyd’s car. gets out, suspicious of the vehicle. As she does Lloyd co barreling out of the house, heading for his car. He sees looking at him as he does. He stops in his tracks, unsure what to do.  82 83 54.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Hi. Lloyd then looks down, gets in his car and drives off. Ro watches him go. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - FOYER, FRONT DOOR - MORNING 82 There’s a knock at the door and Carol answers it. It’s Ro

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hey. What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I brought the new brochures. They have floorplans.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (waving her in) Ah. Right. You want some tea? Rona comes in and Carol shuts the door. INT. CAROL'S HOUSE - KITCHEN —- MORNING 83 The brochures sit on the counter as Carol pours some coff Rona sits at the counter waiting. Carol brings the coffee

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Thanks. Rona curls her hands around the cup.

dialogues.speaker: RONA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So... who was that guy?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What guy?

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: The young guy with the bed head that just pulled out of your driveway.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You’re such a snoop.  55.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I am not a snoop. I come over here and I see some guy leaving your house at eight in the morning. I’m wondering what’s going on, is all.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You know what, it’s none of your business, Ro.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Okay, I know what’s going on here. Are you some kind of cougar?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: A what? Rona laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: A cougar.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What the hell is that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I know what you’re up to. You’re a cougar and I’m proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Get out of here with that.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Just don’t let him videotape it, it’ll be all over the internet.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You would know. Rona laughs again, but underneath it her mood is growing serious.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: You were always the one the guys wanted. Still are, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Ro - stop with that. Why are you talking like that?  56.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: That's just life. Just the way it’s always been. You get the guy. You're just sneaky about it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (looking away) I can think of one guy I didn’t get. Rona looks hurt. This hasn’t been brought up in years.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: You were happily married for twenty- some years and you still think about this?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Every day. Rona shakes her head and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I should go.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No, Ro. It’s...

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: (irritated) What?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Look, forget it. I’1l see you for Bridge tomorrow, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Just... let me know what you think of the brochures. Rona leaves. Carol looks down at the brochures for the retirement community, the word “ROYAL OAKS” emblazoned on cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol walks along the sidewalk in her usual walking outfi Per usual, Mike approaches again with his dog.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey there.  57.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hey, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Nice to see you. Carol stops and pets the dog.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You too, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: You holding up okay?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m doing fine. Just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After her walk Carol pours herself a glass of water and notices her answering machine flashing. She hits the butt

dialogues.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE VOICE
dialogues.text: You have two messages.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey mom. It’s me. I’ve got some frequent flyer miles so I bought a ticket to L.A. You’re right - I haven't been down in a while so I just figured I’d book it. I’1l be in next Tuesday. Hope that’s okay. I’1l call you later. Love you. BEEP. Next Message.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m talking to a machine here I guess but the machine said this was Carol. Carol stops drinking her water and turns to the machine, recognizing the voice.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So Carol, this is Bill. I remembered your number so I thought I'd give you a call. Why don’t you come on down to the clubhouse today around 11. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I‘1l be on the patio waiting for you. If not - hey, no big deal. BEEP. Carol just stands there, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol walks out onto the clubhouse patio and looks around There aren't many people around but she sees Bill (Cigar sitting at a nearby table with an unlit cigar in his mout He’s reading a paper. She approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (looking up from his paper, happy to see her) Hi, Carol. Can I get you anything?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m okay. I didn’t know how to dress or whether to bring my clubs...

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (standing) You're dressed just right. I don’t play golf.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You live on a golf course and you don’t play?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I’m not a fan of the game. Never had the patience. We’re doing something else today. My car is right over here. You ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill opens the passenger door to his car, and extends a h to help Carol in.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Where are you taking me?  90 91 92 59.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bill leads Carol down a dock toward a boat. Bill and Caro stop at a beautiful fishing boat. The name on the boat sa “So What.”

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: “So What?”

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Miles Davis. Carol thinks for a second.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (excited she remembers) Kind of Blue.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You know your stuff. Carol shrugs then looks from the boat to Bill.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t get seasick, do you? EXT. BILL’S BOAT - DAY 91 The boat heads out to sea. Carol stands by Bill as he dri He picks up a cigar and puts it in his mouth. He looks ov to Carol and smiles. The guy is nothing but confidence. EXT. BILL’S BOAT - THE PACIFIC - DAY 92 Bill hooks some bait onto a hook. Carol watches.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You ever fish?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: It's easy. You throw a line in and wait.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That’s it, huh?  60.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Usually, yeah. Good way to get to know someone. And a good excuse to have a few drinks. Bill throws a line in. They have a seat and he pours her glass of wine and hands it to her. He plays with his ciga his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You ever gonna light that thing?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I used to, all the time. Trying to be health-conscious in my latter years.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Yeah. And someone once told me I have an...oral fixation. So... He puts the cigar back into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You do this for all the girls?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I don’t do this for anyone. You're the first one out on my boat.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Would I lie?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I have no idea. I’m being very trusting of someone I don’t know. For all I know you could be a murderer and you brought me out here to kill me and dump me in the ocean. Like in the Sopranos. Bill chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You watched that show?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Every episode.  61.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: That was a great show. Carol smiles. BILL (CONT’D) I usually come out here by myself. I just bought this boat. Took one look at my retirement money and just said - screw it - I’m moving to California and I want a boat.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Where were you living?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Different places. I was living in Kansas City. I don’t have kids. I got no one to leave it to. My plan is to spend it all before I go.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: And how's that going so far?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: So far so good. People retire with all their money and they don’t know what to do with themselves. They just sit. They watch TV. They golf. They go out and eat cheap dinners. They go to the movies. Casinos. I didn’t want to end up like that.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: So what are you doing living with all those people in a retirement community?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I’m a social guy. I don’t like to be alone. Carol nods, taking that in.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I like this, too. I like being out here. Being away from it all. They look out for a while onto the Pacific. It’s serene. BILL (CONT’D) How about you. What are you doing living in a retirement community?  62.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m not.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Not what?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t... (agitated) ...live there.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I have... I have a house.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: So you’ve got your own place. Huh. So how come I see you all the time at Royal Oaks?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’ve got friends there. The Management lets me use the golf course... for a fee, of course.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: So why don’t you have a cell phone? Hell, I even have one.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t like the idea of someone always being able to find me. (thinks more about it) And I like coming home to messages. It’s nice. Carol looks out a the ocean again.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So this is fishing, huh?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: This is it. They call it fishing, not catching.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE OMITTED 93
dialogues.text: 94 EXT. BILL’S BOAT - THE PACIFIC - EVENING 94 The boat drives back to shore as the sun sets.  95 96 63.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful cocktails are delivered to Carol and Bill’s tab Bill and Carol clink glasses. Champagne is poured. Appetizers are served along with a beautiful plate of sea and oysters. Bill and Carol eat and share a laugh. Red wine is poured. The main courses arrive - beautifully presented. Carol takes a bite of delicious food. Bill watches. Dessert arrives and they share a chocolate ganache. Carol, full on food and drink, smiles at Bill. END MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol and Bill enjoy an after dinner cocktail together.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: When did you say your husband passed away?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You still seem somewhat... I don't know, mournful to me.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Do I?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Yeah, there’s like a - you almost seem kind of pissed -

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Pissed?  64.
