dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: - yeah, but in a sad way, if that makes any sense.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Well, my dog died. I had to put him down just last week.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: That must have been sad for you. That would piss me off. I’m very sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes, I've been feeling like - I guess I’m numb. I thought I would feel... more sad. But I am sad. He was everything in the world to me. I can't put my finger on it.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: It’s bittersweet. You can’t let them suffer, but you don’t want to let them go. (pause) It’s hard to lose somebody... no matter how many legs they have. It just leaves a big hole. How old was he?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Fourteen.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You’d been through a lot together.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Do you think he saw it that way? Carol pauses. She touches her wine glass.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you ever lose anyone? A wife, OL...

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: My wife left me. Then she died.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That would piss me off. Bill smiles.  97 65.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I like you a little bit, I think. Yeah. You’re okay.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Just okay?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You’re not fussy.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You don’t know me that well.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: That’s not important. I know you well enough to say you’re okay.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (pausing to look at him) Okay. Scene ends with a wide shot of the candlelit table, the t of them looking at each other. INT. BILL'S CAR (EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE) - NIGHT 97 Bill and Carol pull up to Carol’s house.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thank you for a wonderful evening. Well, day, I guess. She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t remember the last time I just... spent the whole day away from the house. (thinks about it) I had a great time.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Good. I’m glad. They stare at each other for a moment. Carol, unsure of w to do next, smiles and goes for the door.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where’re you going?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Home. Isn’t that where I am?  98 99 100 101 66. Carol looks at Bill and then they kiss. It’s a nice, long passionate kiss. Carol finally pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay... Thank you, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Can I see you again?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Where did you come from? Bill smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol walks into the kitchen still feeling a buzz from th day's activities. She makes herself a cup of coffee. While she’s waiting she stands and gets lost in thought, smiling. Then, out of nowhere, the rat runs across the fl She jumps back, startled. The rat turns and runs in the o direction as she screams and runs out of the kitchen. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - MORNING 100 Carol wakes up on her couch outside, having slept there a night. She rubs her neck and forces herself to get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Exterminator is in the house again. He has a stethosc on his ears and he listens to the wall with it. He remove the stethoscope from his ears and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERMINATOR
dialogues.text: Did you hear anything in the walls overnight?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I... no. I didn’t sleep here last night.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERMINATOR
dialogues.text: I don’t see anything... I don’t hear anything. He might be inside the walls, but... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: EXTERMINATOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ll set a few more traps near your plumbing outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol is on the phone. The ROYAL OAKS brochures are in he hand.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hi.... I understand that you may have a unit available? (listens) No, that’s not necessary. Just wanting to see if it was still available. I’1l call back. Thank you. She hangs up, immediately regretting her call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol’s car pulls into the retirement community. Carol ge out of the car and gathers her things and shuts the door. heads off towards Sally’s apartment. Carol sees a NURSE pushing an elderly NURSING HOME RESIDENT down the sidewal a wheelchair. They make their way to an idling minivan wh another NURSE is waiting with the door open. Carol stops walking and watches as they struggle to get the Nursing H Resident to her feet. She staggers into the minivan and t buckle her inside. It is a long and strenuous process. Carol turns away and keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol, Rona, Georgina and Sally all play their weekly gam bridge. As the girls talk, Carol looks like her mind is elsewhere.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I’m getting another beer. Anyone need a refill?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll split a beer with someone.  68.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I’m not splitting a beer with you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Last time you got your lipstick all over the can and you only had one freaking sip. You want a whole one or not?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: I don’t know... can you pour me a little in a glass? Sally rolls her eyes. She looks over to see Carol lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Carol? You want a refill? No response.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Carol. Carol snaps out of it and looks over to Sally. SALLY (CONT’D) You haven't said a word all night.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m just thinking...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You don’t know, Ro.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: What does she know?

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: You want to share with the group, Carol? You have something you want to tell us?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: There’s nothing to tell.  106 69.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Okay. Be like that, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Can we just play the game here?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Yes, let’s play. Rona, come on.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You want a refill, Carol?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sure. Sally gets up to get more booze when Carol stops her.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Actually... Sally, do you still have any of that medical marijuana?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladies stand around trying to figure out how to smoke of a vaporizer. All the blinds have been closed and the l is on nearby. Georgina has the tube in her hand and Sally trying to help her.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I haven't smoked since the seventies.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: How the heck does this thing work?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: It’s gotta warm up. Georgina tries sucking on it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: There’s nothing coming out of this thing. It’s broken, I think.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Be patient. It’s not warmed up yet.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: This is like pre-heating an oven...  70.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: (to Carol) Have you smoked recently?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No. I can’t remember the last time.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Why am I nervous? My heart’s beating so fast.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Try it now. Pull slow. This thing will mess you up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: I know what I’m doing. All right, all right, let’s get it going. Georgina pulls on the tube, inhales and then exhales a va Rona watches.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: (panicked) Where’s the smoke? How come there’s no smoke?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: It's a vaporizer. I'm not trying to smell up the whole campus!

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: (confused) A vaporizer?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Vapor, Rona!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: (after exhaling) Oh man... Oh jeez... That’s great! The ladies laugh. Sally passes it to Carol who puts the t to her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Ready? Carol nods and takes a big hit.  71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgina and Rona are having a conversation on the sofa. Sally is sitting in an armchair watching them.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: There it is again. Did you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I don’t hear a thing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: You both need hearing aids. Where’s Carol?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In the kitchen!

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: In the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Same place I was when you asked me two minutes ago!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: (looking worried) I knew I shouldn’t have smoked any of this. You've turned me into an advanced Alzheimer’s patient. What is she doing in there?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: It’ll wear off. Just try to relax.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I'm feeling pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: There it is again!

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: What the hell is it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: It’s like a dog barking.  108 72.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: What kind of dog?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Like a little dog. (holds her thumb and forefinger about an inch apart) Like a little teeny dog. (makes little barking noise) Yip!

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Yip?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Yip! Yip!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol is standing in the kitchen, looking at the many kni knacks on the walls and shelves. Rona enters. Rona nods.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Got the munchies?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Just looking around.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This ceramic owl is really staring me down.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: (quietly) I didn’t steal John from you, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I never said you did. I just said -

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: That he was a guy you didn’t get? Do you really think I had anything to do with that? I mean, after you quit singing... you weren’t even together at that point.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It’s fine. Really, Ro.  73.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: It turned out to be a big mistake, anyway. It’s not like we lived happily ever after.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I know that.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: We never came close to what you and Bill had. John wasn’t the husband type. If it’s still hurting you...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It's not.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: (pensive) Do you think that’s what I do, Carol? That I just go after other women’s men?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’ve never judged you, Rona. You know that. I didn’t mean anything by it.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I’ve been married and divorced three times, for Christ’s sake...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Who's keeping score anyway? Rona smiles and Carol.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We found it! Georgina and Sally enter, holding a broken smoke detector GEORGINA (CONT’D) It was Sally’s smoke detector. The smoke detector is in pieces.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: What the hell did you do to that?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: It was yipping like a dog.  109

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Dead battery. We tried to fix it... Georgina hands the broken smoke detector to Rona.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do with this?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: (to Carol) Carol, did you find anything to eat? Everyone stares at Georgina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladies browse the aisles with a shopping cart. Rona fills a large bag with candy from the bulk bin. Carol and Sally throw a few bags of chips into their cart Georgina just stares at a pile of apples in the produce section. Rona fills up a big bag with walnuts and eats a few. Sally throws a box of cereal to Carol. Georgina walks through the frozen section, amazed by everything. Rona eats out of one of her bulk bags and looks around. Carol and Sally laugh as they walk down an aisle. Georgina looks at the pastry section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol walks up to Georgina who can’t stop staring at some food in an aisle.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What’re you doing?  75.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Look at this, Carol. Look how many types of crackers there are. Carol looks at the crackers with Georgina. GEORGINA (CONT’D) Can you believe it? Every flavor you can imagine. Gluten free... When I was a little girl the only cracker we had was a saltine. Now look at it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It is a lot of crackers.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Time moves fast. Our kids are all grown up. I’ve got a pile a grandkids now. But it feels good. It feels good to know I’ve left a mark.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: It just feels like I’ve done my best. And I’m ready, you know? I’m ready for whatever comes next.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: And what comes next? Georgina shrugs and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: I'd like to think I'll get to see Gary again. My whole family...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It must be comforting... knowing that.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Sometimes it is. Sometimes it isn’t. But it’s believing not knowing. (pauses) An afterlife where you get to be with everyone again... It’s such a cliché, isn’t it? Everything perfect.  76. Carol doesn’t answer. GEORGINA (CONT’D) I was raised to believe it. I try and choose to believe it. It is a nice thought. Georgina pauses to reflect.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Do you? Georgina looks at Carol. Her eyes and expression say “no.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Every day, it’s a choice I have to make. Every day of my life. I have more reasons not to believe than to believe. They call that “testing your faith.” (pauses) What about you, Carol? What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. (smiles) I try not to think about it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: Are you doing okay?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I'm fine...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: I pray for you, Carol. I don’t know if it does anything, but it makes me happy, praying for you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (taking her in, realizing it’s true) You are happy, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: I’m blessed. And I’m blessed to have you as a friend. Carol looks at Georgina with a knowing look.  112 77. GEORGINA (CONT’D) Now... which cracker should we get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladies try to put on a straight face as the CHECKOUT scans their items. Fruity Pebbles, apples, a chocolate ba beef jerky, sour patch kids, salt and vinegar chips, milk frozen pizza.

dialogues.speaker: CHECKOUT GIRL
dialogues.text: Having a... party? The girls respond with a delayed laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ladies walk with their grocery cart down the street. Sally is pushing the cart, Georgina is eating handfuls of cereal from the opened box of Fruity Pebbles, and Rona is chewing on a piece of beef jerky. Carol is chugging from bottle of water.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: (pointing at the jerky) You can eat that? How can you eat that?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: It’s good for your gums. As they walk a POLICE CAR pulls up to them and stops. The police officer, OFFICER KAY shines a light on them. He st out of his car and approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER KAY
dialogues.text: Ladies. The girls stop and squint against the light and try to ac straight.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s going on here? The girls look at each other. No one wants to be the one talk. They are still a few degrees away from realizing th they've stolen the shopping cart.  78.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: We've been shopping.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER KAY
dialogues.text: I can see that. But what are you doing in the street?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: There’s no sidewalk. How’re we supposed to get home?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: The neighborhood is not pedestrian- friendly, officer.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: You can’t arrest us, for walking. Can you...?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER KAY
dialogues.text: People usually drive to the grocery store.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Well, we’ve had a few -

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER KAY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: - so we walked -

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: - like good, responsible citizens.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Senior citizens.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER KAY
dialogues.text: Any of you ladies ever heard of a designated driver?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: (reaching into the box of Fruity Pebbles) We didn’t plan that far ahead.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER KAY
dialogues.text: (staring at Georgina for a long beat) Uh-huh. What about this shopping cart?  79.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER KAY
dialogues.text: You plan on returning that? Because technically that’s theft. And then we've got public intoxication...

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Do we look like thieves to you?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER KAY
dialogues.text: (humorlessly) A thief doesn’t have a specific look, ma‘am. A thief is just a person who takes something that doesn’t belong to them.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Well, uh...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (jumping in) We borrowed it. Alphonse said it was okay.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER KAY
dialogues.text: Who’s Alphonse?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: He’s the manager.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Alphonse!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: We're just a bunch of old ladies.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: We’re too old and feeble to carry all these groceries home. You understand.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: And we're turning off just a block up the road, officer. We’re in the Royal Oaks Retirement Village.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER KAY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.  113 80. Officer Kay looks them over.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well... just be safe and stay out of the middle of the road now.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Yes, officer. Officer Kay gets back in his cruiser and drives off. The girls react like teenagers to the whole situation - laugh and high-fiving.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: “Alphonse”? Who’s Alphonse?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I just made it up. They walk off down the street joshing and cracking jokes each other. EXT. SALLY’S HOUSE - BACK PORCH - NIGHT 113 Carol and Sally are sitting on the porch, exhausted, post stoned.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I feel like I need to tune in more.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah? To which things?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You're just stoned.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: No, that’s all worn off. I just feel out of touch, you know? Like I don’t know what’s going on with you anymore.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That's because nothing’s going on with me.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t know.  81.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh, come on Sally. What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Like... I feel like you don’t want to admit how you’re feeling. You just - you don’t share.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: When did I ever share?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I’m just saying - nobody knows how you're really doing.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I would tell you if I knew myself.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: You would? They are quiet for a moment, staring out into the night a

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I guess in the back of my mind I’m starting to be convinced that I’m an utter failure.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: What? How?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Maybe in many ways.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: What on Earth would have convinced you of that?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I feel like I’ve... missed my mark. I’ve left behind my true self.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Left it behind when?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Maybe about forty years ago.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: There’s no such thing as your true self.  114 82.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: That’s a bunch of New Age mumbo- jumbo. If everybody were their true selves... what a world of assholes we'd be living in. We’d all be picking food out of our teeth and making kissy lips at each other like orangutans.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: This is the end, Sally. We’re at the end. And if I were to go right now — (snaps her fingers) - like that, what’s left of me? I mean, Bill’s been gone twenty years. And he’s just gone. I think of him all the time, but besides that, some snapshots, that’s all that’s left of him. And when I’m gone - okay, then Kath is still thinking of us. And when she goes, we’re both gone. We’re all gone. It’s like we never existed. Sally looks at her, stupefied.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Carol, I - I just was worried about you, with Hazel gone, whether you were lonely. Jesus, I didn’t - Carol closes her eyes very slowly, then opens them.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: He was a dog, what more can I say? I walked him every day - Carol chokes up on “day” and breaks down crying. Sally pu her hand on her shoulder and rubs her back, comforting he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol turns on kitchen light, notices her answering machi flashing. She hits the button.  83.

dialogues.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE VOICE
dialogues.text: You have four new messages.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello Carol, this is Bill. I’m just calling to say hello... I’d like to see you again, if you’re not busy this week. Give me a call. BEEP. Next message. BEEP. Next message.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey mom. It’s me. I didn’t hear from you, so just making sure it’s okay that I’m coming Tuesday. Give me a call when you get a chance. Love you. BEEP. Next message.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Carol, it’s Lloyd. Hey. Um, just checking in. Hope things are good. Okay. Bye. BEEP. Next message. She goes to her purse, remembering something. She reaches her purse and pulls out the COASTER from the bar with Llo with “Apple-tini” written on it. She looks at it fondly.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi Carol. Listen. How about tomorrow night? Let me know. BEEP.

dialogues.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE VOICE
dialogues.text: End of messages. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - FOYER, FRONT DOOR - DAY 116 Doorbell rings. Carol goes to the door dressed for a casu evening out. When she opens it, Bill is standing there. H is holding a small bouquet of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hello, stranger. Are those for me?  117 84.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Nah. I just thought I’d carry some flowers around tonight.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: They're beautiful. Come in. I’1l put these in some water. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - DAY 117 Bill and Carol exit Carol’s house just as Rona is walking the front path. Carol sees Rona and stops.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Hot date tonight?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh, Rona... Bill, this is my friend Rona.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you. Did you two have plans?

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I was just coming over to see if Carol wanted to go for a walk, but I see you've already got plans. Rona shoots Carol a look like “not bad.”

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: See you, Rona. EXT. BILL’S BOAT - THE DOCKS - NIGHT 118 Bill has decked out his boat with lights for a romantic, back meal of clams and beer with Carol. They sit and enjo the food. Carol looks around, enjoying herself.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: How are you doing? She looks up and smiles at Bill.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Really good.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE OMITTED 119
dialogues.text: 120 121 85. INT. BILL’S CAR (EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE) - NIGHT 120 Carol sits in Bill’s car.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: So I’m thinking this is going okay.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: That we might spend some more time together. Carol touches Bill’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol goes into the kitchen while Bill wanders around the room, hands in pockets, looking at photographs.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Would you like something to drink?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Are you having anything?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Carol enters. Bill goes to her and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are we doing? Are we doing something?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Because I’m out of practice with this sort of thing. And don’t say it’s just like riding a bike because I can’t ride a bike to save my life.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: It’s just like swinging a golf club.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: How would you know? You don’t play golf.  86. Bill kisses her again. They stop and look at each other, caught up in the moment.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you need anything?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You don’t need one of those pills?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I don’t like pills.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You don’t take any pills? Not for anything?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Not if I can avoid it. I don’t like side effects.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: But you'll be okay?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. You want me to take an aspirin just in case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol turns on her bedside lamp to reveal Bill lying next her in bed. They are both breathing hard and sweaty.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m not so sure about your golfing metaphor.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: No. It really is more like riding a bike, I'd say.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah. A very... nice bike.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: We should do it again.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Not now. (laughs ) I can't.  123 87.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I just meant sometime. I’1l need some time to recover. I hadn’t done this for a long time myself.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t believe that.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: It’s true. They stare at the ceiling then Bill turns to her. BILL (CONT’D) What did your husband do?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (distressed by the question) Why are you asking about my husband?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I’m just curious. I’m just trying to get to know more about you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: He was a lawyer. His name was Bill, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: No kidding. (beat) What was he like? Carol genuinely thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Nothing like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol and Bill have bagels and coffee and orange juice at kitchen table; in the middle of the table, in a vase, are flowers Bill brought for their date. Bill’s hair is musse he’s wearing his clothes from the night before, no shoes. Carol is in a bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It’s supposed to be hot today. We should go for a swim after breakfast.  124 Bill chews his bagel thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Have you ever thought about getting remarried?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I hope you’re speaking theoretically here.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That means you’re not speaking theoretically.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I’m just testing the waters.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Get out of the water. I barely know you.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Is it too soon to ask your thoughts? Just on remarrying, as an idea.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’ve never seriously considered it.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Never?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I've been married. We get married and next thing, what - I'm washing your underwear? Doorbell rings. Carol looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who could that be? Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol goes to the door and opens it. Lloyd is standing 88. 124 there. Carol closes the door partway, blocking the view i the house with her body.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Hey.  89.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hi. Is today a pool cleaning day?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Actually - I quit.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I got another job -

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh. Good.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: - but I wanted to stop by and let you know I wouldn’t be cleaning your pool anymore.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: The owner and I had differences. Or actually, we were in complete agreement that I should not be working there anymore.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I'd already been looking around for something, and an opening came up, so it worked out well.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What kind of job did you get?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Pool cleaner. Another outfit. Pools By Us.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Pool By Us?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: With the economy what it is - it’s not like I’m changing careers, you know? I’ve got skills. They say nothing for a beat.  90.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (meekly) Listen - are we good?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Of course we are. Lloyd nods. Bill appears behind Carol.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh - Bill, this is Lloyd. Bill and Lloyd shake hands. They both appear very confuse

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lloyd, um, is the pool guy.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Pool guy? Oh.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Actually I was just telling Carol that I’m no longer going to be cleaning her pool anymore. I’m moving on to... other pools.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I see. Well, do you want to join us for lunch?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Thanks, though.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Okay. (pauses, unsure what to make of Lloyd) Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: You too. Bill walks off. Carol looks at Lloyd and they smile at ea other.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Lloyd nods and looks around then back at Carol.  gl.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Bye, Carol. 125 INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - DAY 125 Bill puts on his shoes. Carol sits on a chair nearby.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: So when can I see you again?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: My daughter is coming into town tomorrow. I need to spend some time with her and...

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Jesus, did I not tell you I had a daughter?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: No. Though I never asked.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I have a daughter. Her name is Kath. Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Katherine. I'd like to meet her sometime. Carol rubs her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’1l think about it.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. This is all a little new for me.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah? Bill nods.  126 127 128 92.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I like you, Carol. Bill gives Carol a kiss and heads out towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (upbeat ) If I don’t hear from you, I’1l call you in a few days. Have fun. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - DAY 126 KATHERINE (mid 30s) walks up Carol's front path as a TAXI pulls away. Carol comes outside to meet Katherine and the hug.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Hey mom.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: Hi, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol and Katherine have a light lunch. Carol opens her napkin and spreads it in her lap, avoiding eye contact wi Katherine. Katherine takes a sip of water and watches her They sit for a long time not talking.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Mom.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Are we going to talk at all on this visit, or will it mostly just be us sitting quietly like this?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Do you want a glass of wine? I want a glass of wine.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: You go ahead. Carol starts looking for the waitress.  93. KATHERINE (CONT’D) How are you doing, mom?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: I mean, really.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Really. I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: You seem a little... I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Different, I guess. Is it Hazel? Carol waves her off. KATHERINE (CONT’D) You always call me back and you didn’t call me back until yesterday. I was about to cancel my ticket.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I was just busy.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: With what? You’re never busy. Carol rolls her eyes. KATHERINE (CONT’D) I don’t mean it in a bad way, mom. It’s just... you’ve never seemed particularly busy. I think that’s pretty fair to say.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I have a life, sweetie. Hard as it is for you to imagine, I have a life.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: I think that’s great, mom. I was just curious. Silence takes over as Katherine goes back to her salad an Carol starts to look around for a waitress.  94.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Where is that waitress? Carol looks back at Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m seeing somebody.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah. I mean... I don’t know if it's serious, but...

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: I can’t believe it. Is this the first time in... since Dad? Twenty years? Carol doesn’t answer. KATHERINE (CONT’D) I could tell something was different. It’s in your eyes. You're not preoccupied with just... yourself.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (irritated) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Well, you usually are. You know you are.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m preoccupied, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: So what’s he like? What’s his name?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: His name... is Bill.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I didn’t plan it that way.  95.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: How’d you guys meet? On the internet or something?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? I just met him, around. At the grocery store. He asked me out.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: The old-fashioned way.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: He’s a lucky guy. You’re a catch. Carol shrugs and looks around. KATHERINE (CONT’D) So do you like him? How long has this been going on?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: A couple of dates. (thinking about it) Yeah, I like him. He’s... I don’t know. I don’t know what the hell I’m doing. It’s all very new.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, you like him.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Maybe. (changing the subject) So what's new with you. You getting any work?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Well... I’ve got a lead ona teaching job, actually.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (surprised) Really?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Teaching drama at a private school. I think I might get it. It happened really fast.  96.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: This is big news. Not what I expected to hear.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: What do you expect to hear?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t expect anything.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Nice. The vote of confidence.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You know that’s not what I mean. You happy about it?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: I’m happy about it... it’s not acting. Carol looks pensive.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: But it’s good work. I hope you get it.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Thanks. I hope I do, too.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Cheers, mom. They clink glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol and Katherine enter kitchen with a couple bags of groceries and set them on the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: So are you going to call him? I'd like to meet him, actually.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t know.  130 97.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Come on. I’1l make spaghetti and we'll just hang out real casual. We won’t make a big deal out of it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You're making a big deal out of it right now.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Whatever. The answering machine light is blinking. Carol hits the button.

dialogues.speaker: ANSWERING MACHINE VOICE
dialogues.text: You have three messages.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey Carol, I know you said you had plans. I’m just calling to say hello. Carol and Katherine exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: BILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So... hello. That’s all. I/’11 speak to you later. Bye. BEEP. Next message.

dialogues.speaker: RONA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (panicked) Carol, God, I wish you had a cell phone. It’s Rona. I was at the clubhouse and... just call me. BEEP. Next message.

dialogues.speaker: RONA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: For Christ's sake honey, call me on my cell. Call me as soon as you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol and Katherine approach a NURSE at a reception area.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hi. I’m here to see my friend. Bill Young. He was admitted earlier.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Are you a family member?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No. I’m a friend.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. At this time only immediate family are allowed. 98. Carl takes a deep breath, frustrated. Katherine puts a ha on her back.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I'd just like to know if he’s okay, or -

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I can’t give you any information if you’re not a family member. Carol doesn’t respond. The Nurse sees how frustrated she

dialogues.speaker: NURSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you leave your number I’1l try to get someone to contact you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (smiling but still upset) Thank you. Carol and Katherine walk away down the hall. Katherine pu her arm around Carol as they walk.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE OMITTED
dialogues.text: INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - DAY Carol sits with Katherine. They both have some wine.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t know why we do this.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Why we get attached to people in the first place. It’s just so much worry. I barely know this man and now look at me.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Well, you’re a good person.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: When you were young, just a baby - lucky for you that you don’t remember it - you were so sick all the time. I guess like all babies are. Maybe a little more so. It was a lot of illness and hospitals and sleepless nights.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: (attempting to smile) Not really worth it, huh? Carol looks at Katherine.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It was worth it. The PHONE RINGS and Carol gets up to answer it in the kitchen. She steps back into the living room with Katheri

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (on phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mrs. Petersen?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m Ted Lange. Bill Young’s attorney. The receptionist here gave me your number. You’re a friend of Bill’s, is that right?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes I am.  134 100.

dialogues.speaker: LANGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well... I’m sorry to say that Bill passed away. Just a few hours ago. This hits Carol like a knife in the gut. Katherine stands knowing something is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: LANGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What was it?

dialogues.speaker: LANGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It was a stroke. A bad one. He never regained consciousness. There was nothing they could do.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (keeping it together) Thank you for the call. Carol hangs up. Katherine knows what the news is by Carol silence. She walks up to her mom and hugs her. She holds for a long time. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - NIGHT 134 Carol is sitting outside in a pool chair in the dark with cup of coffee in her hands, looking shell-shocked. Kather comes out with a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: You doing okay?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Katherine approaches Carol.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Do you feel like talking?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You've still got a box or two of your things up in the guest room closet. Maybe you’d better go through it before you head back.  135 136 101.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine is on the floor with her cup of coffee, looking through open boxes of photographs, old greeting cards, notebooks. She finds a photograph of her mother, father, herself as a young girl. They are all smiling. The photo about 25 years old. She stands up and takes the photo out the room. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - NIGHT 136 Carol is still sitting in a pool chair in the dark. Kathe turns on the outside light and comes out.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Can you leave that off, please?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: I want to show you something. Katherine has the photo in her hand and hands it to Carol

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (squinting) Where was this?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Maine, I think.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes... Uncle Dave’s cabin in Pemaquid. Carol looks at it as if puzzling it out.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (quietly) How did I end up here?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I never thought I’d be seventy. I just never thought about it and... all of the sudden, here I am.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: That’s good thing. (trying to be upbeat) You’re still here.  102.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Back when this picture was taken getting old was the furthest thing from our minds. I don’t remember ever discussing with Bill, “Why don’t you die in a plane crash, and I’1l grow old alone.” Silence for a beat. Katherine looks at her mother.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: So what were you thinking of?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: When the picture was taken? Carol studies the photo. She shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Pancakes? Katherine laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is it really worth it? Any of it? I mean, look at this. Look at what we had here. We don’t have that anymore.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: So we've got something else. And maybe that’s the point of it. You can regret it all, or you can -

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What’s the point of it all?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: How can you say that, mom?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I just feel like... like I missed something. Incomplete. Like there’s supposed to be something more to it. There has to be something more, right?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: You've had a great life, mom. A full life. You had a great husband, you had a music career, you had a wonderful career as a teacher --  103.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Not that wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: You had me... What else is there?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That’s all in the past tense. Everything you just said, you're telling me about things I had, things I did.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: So? Isn’t that what life is?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Katherine looks at Carol; Carol looks back.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I loved your father, honey. I hope you know that.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: I know, mom. Carol takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: He wanted to get married, this guy.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Bill? Wow. Did you say yes?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No. I was very rude, actually.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: It seems kind of soon to be asking.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Not when you're my age. Time is short, see?

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Well.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I guess he could’ve lived and we could've gotten married and ended up growing old together. But I didn’t know him. So who knows? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe it would’ve worked out. Maybe we would’ve been happy. Katherine reaches for Carol’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: KATHERINE
dialogues.text: Mom. Carol looks at Katherine and slightly smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I wonder what your father and I would be like now... Katherine squeezes Carol's hand. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE - POOL - NIGHT 137 Carol wakes up and sits up in her chair, putting her feet ground. She looks at her daughter asleep across from her the couch. She gets up and sits next to Katherine. She strokes her hair, as if she were little again. FADE TO BLACK. BEGIN MONTAGE: (*Note: This montage is to imply time pass

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RETIREMENT COMMUNITY GOLF COURSE
dialogues.text: Carol plays golf with Sally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Girls play their weekly game of bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol and Mike run into each other and Carol pets Mike’s and catches up with both of them. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - DAY 142 Carol watches from inside her house as a new POOL GUY cle her pool outside.  105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol visits her husband’s grave at the cemetery. His headstone reads: LIFE PASSES, DEEDS REMAIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol walks along the docks, looking at boats as the sun sets. She sees Bill’s boat, “So What,” and looks at it fondly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol walks into the Karaoke Bar that she went to with LL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol walks in. The place is pretty empty. Carol looks ar and has a seat at the bar. A FEMALE BARTENDER walks up to her.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Can I get you something?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’1l have a, uh, apple-tini?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Sure thing. Carol stops her as she goes to make it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Actually, just a Modelo... please. The Female Bartender nods and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is karaoke tonight?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE BARTENDER
dialogues.text: (delivering the beer) That’s only on Thursdays. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh. No problem. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol drinks a Modelo at the bar by herself.  106. END MONTAGE. 148 INT. CAROL'S HOUSE - KITCHEN —- MORNING 148 Carol opens her phone book and looks up a number. She dia on her phone and waits.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hi. Is this Pools By Us? I’m looking to make an appointment.

dialogues.speaker: SCENE OMITTED 149
dialogues.text: 150 INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - FOYER, FRONT DOOR - DAY 150 Carol opens the door to reveal Lloyd in his new pool getu

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Nice uniform.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah. Pools By Us is a little stricter about the dress code. You like it?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It becomes you. I like a man in uniform.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Come on in. Lloyd follows Carol inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol stops and turns around to face Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Do you want something to drink, or?

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m okay.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t need the pool cleaned. The other guy just did it, actually.  107.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah? He do a good job?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Eh. He’s okay. There’s an awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Listen. I’m sorry that I... I came by the other day when your friend was here. Carol doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I should've called first or something. As Lloyd talks, Carol sees the RAT on the other side of t room. She freezes up. Lloyd notices a change in Carol.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (whispering, pointing) Rat. Lloyd turns around and sees the rat, just sitting there. Lloyd grabs a big, clear bowl on the nearby table and tak some fruit out of it. He gets on the far side of the rat, bowl in hand. The rat takes off towards him and he throws bowl over the rat, capturing it.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Got it! The rat runs around, trapped inside the bowl. Lloyd grabs some heavy books and puts them on top of the bowl keeping rat locked in. Lloyd looks up at Carol.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What should I do with it? Should I kill it, or...? Carol looks at Lloyd and then down to the rat trapped in bowl. She breaks down and starts to cry. She sits down on couch and covers her face. Lloyd, confused, stands up, leaving the rat trapped in th bowl, and walks over to Carol.  108.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Carol? Carol continues to cry.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Carol? Carol starts to pull herself together.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I lost a friend. Recently... I... His name was Bill. You met him.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: That’s terrible, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It’s okay, it’s okay. We went on a couple of great dates. A sweet guy. I liked him but, if I’m being honest, I didn’t know him at all. And then he just... Lloyd looks on, listening.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I keep wondering what made his body just...stop. What made it say “I’m done now.” Carol looks at Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just don’t get it, Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: There’s nothing to get. Carol smiles and wipes away some tears.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I hate that fucking rat. This breaks the sadness and the two of them share a laugh

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Catching that rat might be my biggest accomplishment right now.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh, come on.  109.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I’m serious. I'ma bit of a failure, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You’re young. You’ve got a lot more life to...

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Screw it up even more?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You've got plenty to show for it, Lloyd. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: So why can you see that in me and not in yourself? Carol thinks about this.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you can sing.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Sure...

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: I clean pools. (struggling to come up with something to say) I wrote a song.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I want to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Someday I’1l sing it for you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Sing it now.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Really? I need something. A guitar...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’ve got something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd sits with a ukulele in his hand. He strums it awkwa and decides to go for it.  153 110.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: It’s not finished, but... Okay. Carol leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Keep your expectations low. Lloyd sings his song to Carol. He finishes and looks up a her.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m still working on it. I don’t know... There were no pools in it. Carol touches his hand.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lloyd.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: For stopping by and singing me that song. (pause) And for catching the rat.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: Well, I’m glad I was here.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Me too. They lean in and hug. As they pull apart from each other, Carol looks at Lloyd and they look at each other in a way that suggests they are about to kiss. Then they both lean back, looking bemused. It’s unclear to both of them what’ happening. Carol and Lloyd look away and then at each oth again.

dialogues.speaker: LLOYD
dialogues.text: (pointing back at the rat) Should we do something about that guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol and Lloyd watch as the Exterminator removes the rat from the bowl and puts it into a container. He then bags container and heads out of the house. Carol and Lloyd wat him leave.  154 111. Carol and Lloyd watch him leave.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You want a drink? Lloyd smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol sits at a card table playing bridge with Rona, Georgina, and Sally. A hand has been dealt and the four women are holding their cards and rearranging them in the hands. They are drinking their usual.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: I think I gotta get out of here. Go on a cruise or something. You guys want to go with me? Come on, ladies. I know you can all afford it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Depends where you're going.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: And when.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: And why.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Iceland. I don’t know. Anyplace. I told you why. I’m feeling agitated.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I’m assuming you mean horny?

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: (to Rona) That’s what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: I hear good things about Iceland.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m going to New York to see Katherine next month.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: So let’s meet in New York and hop on a boat someplace.  Silence. 112.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I get seasick. And I hear these stories about people getting stranded, or everybody getting sick with horrible diarrhea...

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: That sounds fun, right?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: That fella, he had a boat, didn’t he? Bill?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (quietly) He did. “So What.”

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: (looking hurt) I was just asking.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That was the name of the boat, Georgina. “So What.” More quiet card playing.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: So what ever happened to his boat? And all his stuff? No family?

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Did he really not have anyone?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No family. Really, truly, nobody. Just a lawyer and lots of friends, apparently, judging by the funeral. I did ask his lawyer if I could keep one thing of his.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: They let you keep it? What was it?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It’s a secret.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: So what happened to his boat? To everything?  155 156 157 158 113.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Last I saw his boat it was still at the dock. (pauses) I can’t... I can’t know anything more about him.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: I'd be dying to know.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I know you would. More quiet card playing.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell? Maybe we should go. Iceland sounds nice.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGINA
dialogues.text: It does.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: Now that’s what I’m talking about. I'll bring Dramamine, Rona. You'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: RONA
dialogues.text: And Imodium. The girls share a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol wakes up to her alarm, the clock digits showing 6:0 sharp. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE - DINING AREA - MORNING 156 Carol sits at her kitchen counter with a coffee and a New York Times in her hands. INT. CAROL'S HOUSE - KITCHEN —- MORNING 157 Carol takes some pills and vitamins with water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol is out for a walk and sees Mike out walking his dog They both stop.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Hey you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Haven’t seen you for a while...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I know. They stand there.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Have you ever thought about getting another dog? This guy could use a new pal. And it’d be good to see more of you, too, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I just don’t think I could lose something I love again.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What would you do?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE
dialogues.text: I... I’m 82 years old. If I stopped getting dogs because they die on you... I guess I’d’ve had my last dog when Truman was president. It’s hard, I know. But as long as you enjoy them while they’re here, and they enjoy you... you know, animals die. (looks affectionately at his dog) They break your heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol arranges some things on her mantle. She cleans up around Hazel and Bill's ashes.  161 162 163 164 Al64 115. Next to the ashes we see an unlit cigar wrapped in cellophane. Carol looks at it for a moment and then arran it nicely next to the ashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol walks out her side door to her car and gets in. She starts up her car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol drives down a street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol is being walked through the shelter by a SHELTER WORKER.

dialogues.speaker: SHELTER WORKER
dialogues.text: We've had a lot of dogs come in this year. Are you looking for a particular breed?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m not sure what I’m looking for.

dialogues.speaker: SHELTER WORKER
dialogues.text: That’s okay. All these dogs need a good home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol and the Shelter Worker look at some dogs as they wa Carol comes across a MUTT, sitting quietly in the back of cage. She stops and looks at the dog.

dialogues.speaker: SHELTER WORKER
dialogues.text: That’s Beenie. She’s a sweetheart. Carol looks over at BEENIE, who lies down with her head o her paws. SHELTER WORKER (CONT’D) She’s older. I think she’s about 11 or 12. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 165 116. SHELTER WORKER (CONT’D) The tough thing about dogs like Beenie is that they’re close to the end of their expectant life span and prospective owners have a difficult time with that... It’s too bad. She is a sweetie. A family had to give her up. I forget why... Beenie looks up at Carol. INT. CAROL’S CAR (DRIVING) - DAY 165 Carol drives along. She looks over at the passenger seat. Beenie sits comfort in the seat next to her. END.
